title: Philippians 4:13 Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of Philippians 4:13 — 'I can do all things through Christ which strengtheneth me' — and its true meaning in context.

questions.question: What is the exact wording of Philippians 4:13 in the KJV?
options: I can do all things through Christ which strengtheneth me.
I can do all things through God who gives me strength.
I am able to do all things through Christ who strengthens me.
All things are possible through Christ who strengthens me.
questions.correctAnswer: I can do all things through Christ which strengtheneth me.
questions.explanation: The KJV reads: 'I can do all things through Christ which strengtheneth me.' Other translations use slightly different wording, but this is the exact King James text.

questions.question: In context, what is Paul specifically talking about when he says 'I can do all things'?
options: Being content in any circumstance — whether in need or abundance
Winning athletic competitions for God's glory
questions.correctAnswer: Being content in any circumstance — whether in need or abundance
questions.explanation: In Philippians 4:11-12, Paul explains he has learned to be content whether he is abased or abounding, hungry or full. Verse 13 is the conclusion: Christ gives him strength to be content in all situations.

questions.question: Who wrote the book of Philippians?
questions.explanation: Paul identifies himself as the author in Philippians 1:1: 'Paul and Timotheus, the servants of Jesus Christ, to all the saints in Christ Jesus which are at Philippi.'

questions.question: What were Paul's circumstances when he wrote Philippians?
options: He was preaching freely in Jerusalem
He was studying in a synagogue in Athens
questions.explanation: Paul wrote Philippians while in prison, likely during his Roman imprisonment. He refers to his 'bonds' in Philippians 1:13-14 and mentions 'Caesar's household' in 4:22.

questions.question: True or False: Philippians 4:13 teaches that Christians can achieve anything they want — such as winning a game or getting rich — through Christ.
questions.explanation: This is a common misapplication. In context, Paul is not talking about athletic achievement or prosperity. He is talking about being content in any circumstance — plenty or want, fullness or hunger — because Christ strengthens him to endure.

questions.question: According to Philippians 4:12, Paul says 'I know both how to be abased, and I know how to ___.'
questions.explanation: Philippians 4:12 (KJV): 'I know both how to be abased, and I know how to abound: every where and in all things I am instructed both to be full and to be hungry, both to abound and to suffer need.'

questions.question: What is the source of Paul's strength according to Philippians 4:13?
options: The Roman guards who watched over him
questions.explanation: 'Through Christ which strengtheneth me' — Paul's strength is not self-generated. It comes from Christ dwelling in him and empowering him to endure every circumstance.

questions.question: True or False: Paul says in Philippians 4:11 that he had 'learned' to be content, meaning contentment did not come to him naturally.
questions.explanation: Paul writes: 'I have learned, in whatsoever state I am, therewith to be content' (Phil 4:11). The word 'learned' indicates that contentment was a process of growth, not an automatic gift.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the overall theme of the book of Philippians?
options: Joy and contentment in Christ despite suffering
The end times and Christ's second coming
Rules for church leadership and organization
Rebuking false teachers in the church
questions.correctAnswer: Joy and contentment in Christ despite suffering
questions.explanation: Philippians is often called the 'epistle of joy.' Despite writing from prison, Paul uses the words 'joy' and 'rejoice' over 16 times. The letter teaches that true joy comes from Christ, not from circumstances.

questions.question: What promise does Paul give in Philippians 4:19?
options: My God shall supply all your need according to his riches in glory by Christ Jesus
The Lord will give you the desires of your heart
You shall receive power when the Holy Ghost comes upon you
All things work together for good to them that love God
questions.correctAnswer: My God shall supply all your need according to his riches in glory by Christ Jesus
questions.explanation: Philippians 4:19 (KJV): 'But my God shall supply all your need according to his riches in glory by Christ Jesus.' This promise of provision follows Paul's teaching on contentment.

questions.question: According to Philippians 4:6-7, what is the result of bringing your requests to God with thanksgiving?
options: The peace of God, which passeth all understanding, shall keep your hearts and minds
God will grant every request you make
Angels will be sent to protect you from harm
You will receive double what you ask for
questions.correctAnswer: The peace of God, which passeth all understanding, shall keep your hearts and minds
questions.explanation: Philippians 4:7 (KJV): 'And the peace of God, which passeth all understanding, shall keep your hearts and minds through Christ Jesus.' God promises peace, not necessarily the specific answer we want.

questions.question: True or False: The word 'strengtheneth' in Philippians 4:13 means Christ gives Paul physical or superhuman power.
questions.explanation: The Greek word 'endunamoo' means to empower or make strong inwardly. In context, Christ strengthens Paul spiritually to endure hardship and find contentment — not to perform feats of physical power.

questions.question: To which church was the book of Philippians written?
questions.explanation: Paul addressed the letter 'to all the saints in Christ Jesus which are at Philippi' (Phil 1:1). Philippi was a Roman colony in Macedonia (modern-day Greece), where Paul had established the church during his second missionary journey.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Philippians 4:11: 'I have learned, in whatsoever state I am, therewith to be ___.'
questions.explanation: Philippians 4:11 (KJV): 'Not that I speak in respect of want: for I have learned, in whatsoever state I am, therewith to be content.' This verse sets the context for the famous verse 13.

questions.question: Which verse says 'My grace is sufficient for thee: for my strength is made perfect in weakness,' echoing the same theme as Philippians 4:13?
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 12:9, God tells Paul: 'My grace is sufficient for thee: for my strength is made perfect in weakness.' Like Philippians 4:13, it teaches that God's power works through human weakness, not through human strength.
